Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an LC-MS/MS to Enable Research and Training for Chemistry and Biology Students at SUNY Cortland
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Jeffrey Werner from SUNY Cortland and colleagues Christa Chatfield, Terrence Fitzgerald, Patricia Conklin and Francis Rossi will acquire a linear ion trap mass spectrometer with integrated liquid chromatography separation (LC/MS). The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) use of proteomics time series analysis to optimize open microbial communities in a bioreactor producing extended carbon chain commodity chemicals; (b) identification of larval trail pheromones that could be exploited to reduce insect-related crop damage; (c) elucidation of the physiological mechanisms of environmental biofilm formation involving Legionella pneumophila; and (d) determination of the role of VTC3 in the regulation of ascorbic acid in plants.

Mass Spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. An instrument with tandem capability provides additional structural identification power through further fragmentation of ions produced in the spectrometer. As a primarily undergraduate institution, SUNY Cortland's faculty embraces undergraduate research experiences as one of the most important outcomes of their research activities. The proposed instrument will directly impact the research experiences of at least 28 students within the three-year project period, and many more in years to come. The added synergistic benefit of enhanced capabilities on campus will also increase competitiveness for external funding, further facilitating and enhancing undergraduate research experiences. Undergraduate researchers will travel to high-needs school districts to share their experiences with high school students. Their authentic narratives of scientific inquiry will inspire future scientists as to the leading-edge research one can do as a college student. Ultimately, the goal of these high school connections is to enhance the diversity of students entering science and technology fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Faculty in the departments of Chemistry and Biological Sciences at the State University of New York College at Cortland (SUNY Cortland) have completed research, educational, and outreach supported by a 2013 grant (NSF 1337695) from the National Science Foundation Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program. The MRI grant supported the acquisition of a liquid chromatography mass spectrometry (LC-MS) instrument, currently housed and maintained in the Chemistry Department at SUNY Cortland, a primarily undergraduate institution in central New York. The new instrument provided, and continues to provide, the essential capabilities of separating and identifying organic compounds in a complex mixture, including the ability to identify metabolites and proteins in biological samples.

This project has enabled hands-on training and research experiences for undergraduate students at SUNY Cortland. One of the foremost goals of research at SUNY Cortland is the authentic experience it provides for undergraduate students. The four research projects supported by this grant, described below, facilitated full time summer research experiences for twelve undergraduate students at SUNY Cortland, two of whom did two summer research seasons. Training also included formal classroom / teaching laboratory experiences in which students worked in month-long projects in the Chemistry Department's courses in Analytical Chemistry and Advanced Lab 1. The new LC-MS capabilities, combined with the department's existing gas chromatrography-mass spectrometry system, ensures that every student majoring in Chemistry, Biochemistry, or Adolescent Education-Chemistry at SUNY Cortland gets significant hands-on experience (multiple week independent use) of a chromatrography-mass spectrometry system. Additionally, students taking Microbiology at SUNY Cortland have participated in research enabled by this project. Outreach that was supported by this project included annual visits of Cortland faculty and experienced undergraduate student researchers to local high school and middle school groups, to give potential future scientists the opportunity to hear the stories of what it is like to be a science major in college, what it's like to do scientific research, and what career opportunities are available in the fields of chemistry and molecular biology.

This project facilitated and supported four research projects conducted by five faculty.

  • Dr. Frank Rossi (Chemistry) and Dr. Terry Fitzgerald (Biology), and their undergraduate research advisees, identified and tested trail compounds of the larvae of Cactoblastis cactorum (the cactus moth) which can be used to confuse the larvae and prevent them from establishing a colony within a cactus. As a result, several of the identified compounds are currently being evaluated by the US Department of Agriculture, in field trials, to test their potential use as a species-specific control for Cactoblastis cactorum, to prevent crop damage.
  • Dr. Christa Chatfield (Biology) and her undergraduate research advisees detected amyloid structures in the biofilms of the bacterial pathogens Legionella spp. Understanding the structures of Legionella biofilms is key to understanding the survival and propagation strategies of these bacteria in human-constructed environments. Research in Dr. Chatfield's lab also contributed to the finding that the enzyme agmatine deiminase provides the infectious bacterium Camphylobacter jejuni with resistance to the key last-line antibiotic ciprofloxacin.
  • Dr. Patricia Conklin and her undergraduate research advisees confirmed the identity of epitope tagged GDP mannose epimerase expressed in transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana plants. This biosynthetic protein is at a regulatory junction, so its regulation is of considerable interest. Plants have the capacity to respond to oxidative stress by production of ascorbic acid via the Smirnoff-Wheeler pathway. One step in this pathway involves the conversion of GDP-D-mannose to GDP-L-galactose by the enzyme GDP-D-mannose 3,5-epimerase (GME), and the phosphorylation of this enzyme is important to our overall understanding of how plants respond to oxidative stress.
  • Dr. Jeffrey Werner and his undergraduate research advisees determined the structures of bacterial communities in bioreactors that were engineered to convert organic waste into medium chain carboxylic acids (commodity chemicals and potential precursors to biofuel products). They found a large diversity of bacteria harboring genes for the key pathway used to extend the length of carbon chains in volatile fatty acids (the reverse beta oxidation pathway). More importantly, they found that a wide variety of bacteria within the bioreactors were expressing and using this pathway, implying that these open community bioreactors could potentially be sustainable and robust over long-term operation, supporting the development of this new green biotechnology.
